questionList.questionText: Which statement is true with regard to aircraft converging at approximately the same altitude?

questionAnswers.answerText: A jet airliner has the right of way over all other aircraft.
An aircraft towing objects has the right of way over all power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft.
An aeroplane has the right of way over all other aircraft which are converging from the left.
Aeroplanes towing gliders must give way to helicopters.

questionList.questionText: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude

questionAnswers.answerText: both aircraft shall alter heading to the left.
the aircraft on the right shall avoid the other by descending.
the aircraft that has the other on its right shall give way.
the aircraft that has the other on its left shall give way.

questionList.questionText: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude, which statement applies?

questionAnswers.answerText: Gliders shall give way to helicopters.
Aeroplanes shall give way to power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft.
Gliders shall give way to aeroplanes.
Power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft shall give way to gliders.

questionList.questionText: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude, which statement applies?

questionAnswers.answerText: Gliders shall give way to helicopters.
Aeroplanes shall give way to helicopters.
Helicopters shall give way to aeroplanes.
Helicopters shall give way to gliders.

questionList.questionText: When two aircrafts are converging at approximately the same altitude, which statement applies?

questionAnswers.answerText: Gliders shall give way to helicopters.
Aeroplanes shall give way to helicopters.
Helicopters shall give way to aeroplanes.
Gliders shall give way to balloons.

questionList.questionText: When converging at approximately the same altitude

questionAnswers.answerText: balloons shall give way to hang gliders.
aeroplanes towing gliders shall give way to balloons.
balloons shall give way to gliders.
balloons shall give way to airships.

questionList.questionText: When two power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude,

questionAnswers.answerText: the one on the left has the right of way.
both shall alter heading to the left.
the one on the right has the right of way.
the one on the right shall give way by descending.

questionList.questionText: When two aircraft are approaching head-on or approximately so and there is danger of collision, each pilot shall

questionAnswers.answerText: decrease airspeed.
increase airspeed.
alter heading to the right.
alter heading to the left.

questionList.questionText: When overtaking an aircraft at your 12 o’clock position, at your altitude, you should

questionAnswers.answerText: climb.
descend.
alter heading to the right.
alter heading to the left.

questionList.questionText: Two aircraft are on approach to land, the aircraft at the higher altitude shall

questionAnswers.answerText: have the right of way.
overtake the lower aircraft on the left.
give way.
complete a 360° turn to the right.

questionList.questionText: A series of green flashes directed at an aircraft means respectively (in flight; on the ground)

questionAnswers.answerText: cleared to land; cleared to taxi
return for landing; cleared for take-off
return for landing; cleared to taxi
cleared to land; cleared for take-off

questionList.questionText: A steady red light directed at an aircraft means (in flight; on the ground)

questionAnswers.answerText: give way to other aircraft and continue circling; stop
give way to other aircraft and continue circling; taxi clear of landing area in use
airport unsafe do not land; taxi clear of landing area in use
airport unsafe do not land; stop

questionList.questionText: A series of red flashes directed at an aircraft means respectively (in flight; on the ground)

questionAnswers.answerText: airport unsafe, do not land; taxi clear of landing area in use
give way to other aircraft and continue circling; stop
do not land for time being; return to starting point on airport
you are in prohibited area, alter course; stop

questionList.questionText: A steady green light directed at an aircraft means respectively

questionAnswers.answerText: cleared to land; cleared to taxi
return for landing; cleared to taxi
return for landing; cleared for take-off
cleared to land; cleared for take-off

questionList.questionText: A flashing white light directed at an aircraft on the manoeuvring area of an airport means

questionAnswers.answerText: stop
return to starting point on the airport
cleared to taxi.
taxi clear of landing area in use.

questionList.questionText: Blinking runway lights advises vehicles and pedestrians to

questionAnswers.answerText: return to the apron.
vacate the runways immediately.
be aware that an emergency is in progress; continue with caution.
be aware that an emergency is in progress; hold your position.

questionList.questionText: Chrome yellow and black strips painted on pylons or on the roof of a building identifies

questionAnswers.answerText: an area where explosives are in use.
a fur farm.
an artillery range.
an open pit mine.

questionList.questionText: Pilots should not overfly reindeer or caribou at an altitude of less than

questionAnswers.answerText: 2,500 feet AGL.
2,000 feet AGL
1,500 feet AGL
1,000 feet AGL
